The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to Co.’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: FEMALE EDUCATION AND ' EMANCIPATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: SATURDAY, APRIL 20, 1907

An interesting discussion hi vs recently been carried on in the Press relative to the question of the emancipation of the Moslem woman. Certain differences of opiniQn as to the advisability of tile step have, of bourse, been recorded from the Moslem side, while on the side of the non-Moslem advocates of female emancipation wo note a certain indifference to.questions of çlimate, ami environment which musk be taken into account, if any reasonable conclusion is to be reached. If by emancipation is meant the abolition of the veil and the according of jpermission to Moslem women to mix freely with men in society, wé are in favour of it, with the proviso, that a thorough moral and intellectual education must preccdo any general removal of the barriers which in most Eastern countries imprison, but defend, the fair sex. It must be remembered that the great majority of customs relating to marriage among. Rte various races of the world are to be explained by climatic and physiological causes, A race among which the sexes do not reach ihaturity till comparatively late will naturally allow a greater fieedoin to its womankind than one in which development is precocious. It is, therefore, obvious enough why the peoples of the semi-tropical countries, not merely Moslems, but. the ■ Persians of Mogian times, Hindus, southern Chinese, and even the Athenians, on reaching a certain stage of civilisation should seclude women of marriageable age with greater or leas rigour. There* is nothing in the fount of Islamic doctrine, we refer to the Koran, which can serve aa an excuse for seclusion and there is every reason to believe that the Beni-Omeyya women, though not permitted quite the same freedom as obtained in northern Europe in those days, enjyyed, nevertheless, privileges which are denied to the great majority of Moslem women to-day. Witness the story of the poet Omar ibn- Mogheerah of the. Koreish, .who courted Fatimah, daughter of the Klutlif Abdel Melik, son of Merwan, and recounted his unsuccessful courtship—which we may say WAS clandestine but honourable—in verse that has ever been famous. Under the Abbasides a poet who made free with the name of the Khalif’s daughter would have had «doubtful chance of life, and under Persian or Turkish monarch* there would not have been any doubt whatever as to his fate. But the Beni-Omeyya were still Arabs in Omar’s days and the good Arab of tho deserts and steppes of Arabia allowed « freedom to his womankind that WAS unknown in tho rest of the Eastern world. Chivalry and respect to women have always marked the pure Arab, and oven to-day, accord;, ing to Palgrave, the armies of the clans c Nejd are ‘headed by a maiden, the standi bearer and arbitress of fight.’

But the non-Arab influences that were brought to bear on the Caliphate in the later days when the warlike Turk could boast—‘what use of Arabs without the prophet and angelic aid'—extinguished the old freedom and tended, though there have always been exceptions, to drive the Moslem woman into a position of social inferiority. Islam indeed improved her legal status, which is theoretically high, but ignorance dnd seclusion must prevent an uneducated woman from taking full advantage of her personal rights. We quite admit that an educated Moslem woman is legally in a vèqj. good position, but can she, if uneducated, always avail herself of Moslem law ? Here again it is - not a question of- religion bjit a question of custom - that we are discussing; not Islam that we criticise but Orientalism. To-day the Moslem peoples are, with few exceptions, exposed to new influences which must, to the more Conservative among them, appear dangerously subversive. But in our opinion these influences are not to be met by opposing' stubborn resistance with inadequate means to invincible forces. In Turkey the demands of the Osmanli women * are growing more vigorous daily, and capable observers such as Professor Ramsay believe that'thu Ottoman Empire- will sooner or later find'"'lts political and spiritual salvation in yielding to the demands of half the inçinbers of its ruling caste. In Egypt there are signs that wo shall one day be faced with the same demand. What then will. Ix/'the policy of f liberal Moslems ? In our opinion freed.su without education would be disastrous, education without freedom cruel. Tho two are necessary and. inseparable concomitants—that is if wo define education as the training of the mental and spiritual faculties, for a little music aud the ability to read French or English novels, does not necessarily qualify à woman for emancipation, unless the tradition of liberty is, so to speak, in lier blood. Here this tradition is absent, and it will -therefore he necessary to devote tlie utmost care to .the- training not only of the character, but of the intellect.- That the changes will come we are convinced, and in the meantime £he one way to prepare for it is'fo be fotkpd in education.

div.head: THE MARBLE CITY OF MARIOUf.
div.p: The discovery of .the long lost site of the City of Saint Menas is due to two German archrcologiste, the Rev. C. M. Kaufmnnn and Mr, F. C. fiwald Falls. They,left Frankfort with the object of exploring the famous old Christian remains in Cyrenaica, especially in the hinterland of Djebel Akhdar. However, they could effect not hit g, for the Pasha of Benghasi made ■difficulties, as at the moment of their arrival Tnrkey was disputing with Italy on the question of the harbour at Tripoli, and all endeavours of Europeans to euter the country were, especially at that time, looked npon askance. They had anotlwr scheme in reserve, which was to find the site of Kara Abou Mina, and so they set out for Egypt. On arriving at Alexandria they received some valuable assistance from Dr. Scbiess Pasha and left Alexandria for the Mariout district in May, 1905. They knew that the old Christian oity lay somewhere in the Eastern comer of the Libyan desert in the neighbourhord of Alexandria, hut they had no clear literary directions os to the exact whereabouts of the site. All that they knew was that the sauctuary of Saint Menas' was situated to tho west of Alexandria Such anthoritieg^as John Nikiou, Abu Silih and Makrizi do not mention it. Bat in the history 6f the Patriarchs by Scverus we are told that Benjanim the Patriarch when flying to the mountain Pemudj (the Natron Valley) left Alexandria by the West Gate of the City whence he went on foot to Marea and afterwards to the Oasis city of A1 Mina where he adored the holy Menas in the great sanctuary. Their only other gnidp was The did Arab writer, whose description of the city appeared in bur issue of Tuesday last.
DISCOVERY OF THE SITE.

The two German arcluuologists made a thorough search for the site. They Went as far south as Wady Natron "and Moglmrn and explored all the old ruins in Mariout. After journeying for thirty days on camel back the}’ eamoon June 7, 1905, to a spot, covered with ruins, called Bounina by the Bedouin. On goihg over this place Mr. Ewald Falls fourni quantities of old pottery lying about on the ground, which was.evidently from broken ampulla*. Only a single. Bedouin tent was to be seen in the neighbourhood. A hoy came out of it on seeing th^visitors and showed the German explorers a perfect' ampulla! with the image of Saint Menas on it. He pointed out to them the very spot where ho had found it and they thought it advisable to begin digging there. Now at last it dawned upon them that their weary journeyings were at an end and that here.they were on the very site of the ancient city wlùch hail once been so famqus throughout Christendom but whose site had been unknown for hundreds and hundreds of years. As-soon as'they begun to dig they discovered a large oven filled with numbers of lamps and a collection of benutifuUampullao, which dre now in the Frankfort Museum. The same day they found traces of a large apsidal building in a ruinous state. The name of this deserted spot showed them that they had at last attained theirgoatfor Bounina,Kara a Bounina, was clearly a corruption of Kami Abu Mina Here then was the site of the old city, which Severus in his history of tho Patriarchs avers was more splendid than any of the Christian monuments of Alexandria and all Egypt.
THE EXCAVATIONS.

Tho discovery of the famous old city aroused the greatest interest, in Europe anTt it ,Was at once recognised that a most valuable addition had been made to the science of Christian archaeology. The city of Frankfort* decided to liberally support the work and five months after the finding of tho site the excavations were begun. When w«. visited the site a few days ago it was evident that no expense or pains have been spared to excavate the old city with all that thoroughness that have made German savants famous throughout the learned world. Four basilicas, three of which have been entirely excavuted, have been discovered and tlie crypt of Saint Menas, the great baptistery, many other sacred buildings, and baths,

* The* idea o(. a city sugportiug an expedition lor archaeological research appear* to, the English mind an extraordinary example of municipal aberration. In point of population Frankfort-on-the-Main, comet between Hull and Bristol. If either .of thoeo oities ventured to proposo the expenditure of publio money on such a scheme, tho ory of “Wastrel" would be it ones raised and tho publio career of i ts supporter» „ ould be ruined for ever !

cemeteries and such like appurtenances of a populous city have been brought to light The most interesting find is that ot the sanctuary of the Patron Saint of the Libyan Desert. It is in the oentre of the city and covers a loftily situated area of about seven thousand square metres.t ,

div.head: BASILICA OF ARCADIUS.
div.p: The basilica of the Emperor Arcadius was a most imposing structure. It was covered with marble and supported by fifty columns. The bases are still standing and it is easy to gauge the vast dimensions of tho original building, which was fifty-seven metres long and fifty metres broad in the transepts. The walls were entirely covered with marble and it is obvious from marks on the marble that the building was destroyed by the agency of fire It is a subject for congratulation that so laige a quantity of exquisitely sculptured capitals and other remains of this basilica still exist to bear witness to its former magnificence. The pavement of the building consisted of what is called inalattum or large plaques of marble. There is marble everywhere and it is an evidence ol the veneration of the shrine and of tho expense which the building must have cost, that silch an abundance of this material should have been brought to this spot to deck the basilica. Under the apse of the basilica are threo vaulted sepulchral chambers. Before them the bema seen. It is a semicircular throne with steps. It served for theklerus of thechiirchand is in front of tho high altar. The site of the altar is fixed by the four pillars of the cibovium or baldachin. The bema altar and the site of the amba (pulpit) were enclosed in} a rectangular sort of caucelli aad thus separated from the public throng of worshippers. The atrium was in tho south where three portals open to the basilica. Connected with it are a sérias of sepulchralehambers, large underground cellars with footsteps down to them. At. the end of the basilica, as the anonymous Arabic writer states, is the crypt of Saint Menas. The excavators found the crypt covered with earth to the depth of from eight to twelve metres and here were a large utfiaber of camels heads. It.was a most nrdJrcms task to penetrate into the c'rypt, and some difii- cuflt excavating work had to be undertaken
THE CRYPT AND TOMB.

Two porticoes open on to the crypt from the wast and north, both of which had been elaborately decorated with marble. Through one of the porticoes one reaches the sepulchral ohambers with “dipinto” inscriptions and many graffiti, most of which allude to Saint Menas. The other portico leads down a fine marble staircase of thirty steps going directly to the burial, chambers. The tomb was on the south wall of the crypt, which consists of a large cavern withrtraces of mosaics. It is connected, with a chapel and the catacombs. The actual tomb of the Saint, as the Rev. C. M Kaufman has proved from the discovery of many pieces of’carved wood, was a* wooden reliquary.of a similar sort to those in. the Coptic Monasteries of the Wady Natron. Over the tomb was a marble relief ,of Saint Menas between the adoring camels. This relief, marble traces of which can still be seen, was 1.80 by 1,80 metres in size. Thé place in the well where it was attached is in a perfect state of preservation. All about lie pieces of columns, capitals and marble fragments with crosses. A large opening of hcmicircular shape allows the visitor to look down into the crypt from tho church, under which the tomb is. Tho worshipper gazed down into the beuutifuiy decorated tomb from above, as is the casé in Rome to-day and saw the lamps, which were ever kept burning in the sanctuary. The Menas basilieaunder which tho grève lies is the oldest part of the Sanctuary, the basilica 6f Arcadius being merely an enlargement. There are three apses in the Meim-s basilica and many chambers one leading into the other. One of the most interesting features there is the. holy well, which consists of a great cistern 8G’metres lông, in which thousands of ampullae.» were discovered.
THE MONASTERY.

Nowhere in Egypt are there such vast remains of ancient Christianity as here and the baptistery, which is in the centre of the city, was the finest throughout north Africa. But of all the remains none is more interesting than the monastery, or-Koinobion, of Saint Menas. It was the largest building ot the kiud in the old Christian world and covered ipi area of forty thousand square metres. It*was twice the size of. the celebrated convent of Saint SimeonStylitéfli(\northern 8yria(Kalat Seman) or the Byzantine convent of Thobessa. Excavations are now being made on this site. When the city was first discovered the site was covered with o series of lowmouuds. There was not a wall or trace of the building to be seen. But sincie this part began to be excavated this winter -great progress has been made in spite of the difficult nature of the work. The pavements of fifty rooms, corridors and halls have been unearthed at from four to fiye metres underground.-Enteringby a portico, which was formerly vaulted, the visitor qau inspect a series of rooms. Two courts with large cisterns have been opened up and a great, deal of marble and blocks of fine granite, the latter probably from Tapoairis Magna are to he seen. In this part of. the convent some curious little statues of mo nkeys were found. In the baths of the Koinobitfn numbers of amphorae aild ampullae for holy water were discovered, many of them with inscriptions. The Rev C. M. Kaiifmann con aiders that from the various pottery ovens found here and-other indications that all the

h For those of our roodora with desire more elaborate, details of the lisoovrio. we may refer them to tho two official puMioation,, the latter ol which luts just .been published. Both publications at, issued by Dicmer'a Library, Cairo.

ampullae of Saint Menas, which have been found elsewbewpsacb M at Konr el-Shougafah, were made in the factory hero, for over eighty different kinds of ampullae have been lound lately, in the mine and many thousands more are still buried in the earth. Among other noteworthy buildings are the batlis connected with the baptistery. They were fitted with waiting rooms and supplied from large cisterns twenty-two metres deep. A reservoir, forty by seventy metres, has-been found close by. In another part of the Koioobion a dining hall has been discovered. It was probably reserved for distinguished guests. Here was found a magnificent relief in white marble. The roof of this hall was supported by columns and the walls were covered with marhleand porphyry. The Rev. G. M. Kaufmann informs that judging from the numerous fine capitals, whiotuhaveof late been found on the west aide of the iponastery, lie hopes to come upon the Church of Saint Thekla, which is mentioned in the. life of the Saint.- This church was within.the Koinobion and probably some highly important discoveries will be mode there
THE WATER SUPPLY.

There were probably at least five thousand permanent residents in the oity and this number must have been considerably increased during the pilgrimage season. There were wells as the Arafc^faveller notes, but it is evident 'that the water supply was chiefly from rain. Over fifty huge cisterns have been discovered and there are clear traces of irrigation canals for supplying the city with water from this sourco. On the few occasions when it does rain at Boumna the downpour is ’ excessive and a tringle such shower would fill up all the cisterns. The water supply was clearly sufficient and there are traces everywhere of old almond trees, olives and vine roota.The springs khroughout the whole district are very inferior to what they were in ancient times.

There are only three sweet water springs With a full supper supply in the Mariout district at Hammam, Bir-es-Saleh near Beheig, And Bir Sakkaxah. West of Sidi Ahd el- Rahman the wells are frequent and plentiful. The min water cisterns at Bonmna are in many cases in perfect preservation and'one of the features of a visit to the ruins are the descents into them by means of rope ladders.

It is evident that some settlement existed here in Ptolemaic times, for traces of Greek graves of that epoch have been found there, and the date is fixed by the lamps and glass discovered in these tombs. There are also traces of an old Egyptian monument, but they a« so meagre that it is not known whothor they belonged. to a temple oi not, These remains are tj be accounted for from the fact that the site was oh the caravau road to Nitria from Alexandria. Old cisterns exist at frequent intervals tcf the west, and there was was constant communication between Alex*' andria and Barca by a high road running close by the city.

In some months time the work of Unearthing the old city will come to an end. The German archieologista will betake themselves e! sewhere, and thé si te of the holy city, which has bben of late so- rudely disturbed by the labours of the Bedouin workmen, will again become neglected and unknown, save on the rare occasions when some student of Christian Archieology from Europe or some curious visitor from Alexandria make a pilgrimage to th e ruins of tho city of Egypt's Patron Saint, Saint Monas of Alexandria

div.head: ‘NEW TYPEWRITING RECORD.
div.p: 0,000 WORDS AN HOUR./

The world's record in rapid typewriting was broken in London on the llth.in8t.by a young man from Newcastle on-Tyne, who accomplished the astonishing feat of typewriting 2,500 words from dictation in thirty minutes, and of copying from typewritten “manuscript” 4,800 words in onp hour.
The half-hour’s typewriting from dictation was done at the rate of nearly eighty-four words a minute, or eighty-two words a minute uot countjng words in which letters were incorrectly typed.
The hoar test worked out at eighty words a minute counting all words written, and seventy- eight a minute deducting mistakes.

Previously the best authentic record was that recently made by a young American typist, Miss Rose L. Fritz, who, at the Chicago Coliseum, wrote for half an hour at the rate of seventy-seven words a minute.
Engineer Champion.

Mi. James Wright, a typist in the employment of the engineering firm of Messrs. Scott and Mountain, of Newcastle, is the record- broaloer. A year ago he wrote 30,096 words in seven hours from dictation. A few days ago the “Express” suggested to Mr W. J. Richardson, chairman of the Bar-Lock Typewriter Company, that an attempt should he made to Capture the typewriting record for England, and Mr. Richardson invited Mr Wright to come to London and essay the task. His firm gave him three days’ leave for the purpose.

Mr. Bernard’de Bear, principal of Pitman’s Metropolitan College, agreed to conduct the tria), and at a room in Pitman’s School in Southampton-row, Mr. Wright wrote against time, in the presence of Mr. do Bear, Jnr. F. Heelis, secretary of Pitman’s, aptUpro- siduuf of tho Incorporated Society of Shorthand Writers, Mr. Richardson, and an "Express” representative.

Speed tests in Aiqoriea are frequent, and it is a oommon practice for the typist to write outa single sentence over ami over again, and to reckon that a satisfactory trial. Mr. Wright undertook a much more difficilt work. In both the half-hour dictation test ami the hour's copying, f he type-wtote matter in which there was no repotititm, And. which he liad never written before/

Mr. do Bear chose for dictation Mr. Chamberlain’s speech at Birmingham on May 15, 1903. The hour’s copying test oensisted of speeches made by the late Ijord Russell of Killowou and Mr Haldane at an Eighty Club meeting.

If the test had been taken from the ordinary language of business, Mr. Wright would have made an even better record, for in taking several minutes dictation from Pitman's Commercial Correspondence," he wrote at the rate of 100,101, And 105 words a minute. He has written os many as 116 words in a minute in ordinary business.

As a teat of endurance the hour’s copying was quite as wonderful as the half hour from dictation was as a test of pure speed. At the end Mr. Wright smiled, rubbed Iris aras, and said. “I could have done better if there had not been so many long words " f *
Theheadsof the Pi tmauestablishment agreed that the reoord as it stood was cjgite beyond anything they had previously seen. \

The Bar-Lock Typewriter can be obtained from Witehead Morris & Co. (Egypt) Ld, 14 Rue Sesostris Alexandria and 11 Sharia el Madabegh Cairo who are the sole -agents for the machine in Egypt and the Sudan.

Messrs. MoLAREN, Engineers, of Leeda, England, have sold a large number of Steam Ploughs and Kassabiehs in Egypt this year. Everyone who has land, to cultivate, or to level, should see them at work. Amongst the purchasers are His Highness Prince Hussein Kamel Pacha, His Highness Prince Halim ; The Wardan Estates Company have purchased seven Machines, Messrs. Zagdoun Freres two Machines, also Messrs. Jatrodakis, Bushrahanna, Alexandre Kouri Haddad, Mr. R. P. McGillivray, etc. They can be seen at work any time on application to Mr. Peter McLaren, our permanent representative in Egypt, at Shepheard’s Hotel, Cairo, or tb our Agents, Messrs. Thos.^bR^fe Son (Egypt] Ltd., Boulac Engine Works, Cairo. Full information may also be obtained from Messrs.~J. & H. MoLAREN, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, England;'

Nous détachons d’une correspondance d'A- 'lexandrfe, en date d’hier, le passage suivant :

" Lt réunion des diieoteurs des établisse . menti de banque, des courtiers en valeurs et des chefs des prinoipaloa maisons d’Alexan- dris, qni s'est tenne avanbhier, poor aviser aox mesures qu’exigeraitla situation.do marché fioanoier, ne s’est pas arrêtée à des résolutions définitives ;mait les vnes exprimées daqs oettè assemblée n’en ont pas moins en poor effet de rassurer les esprits. Toot d’abord il a été établi que cette sitaation n'était pas aussi grave qu’on se plaisait à le prétendre. Il ressort, en outre, de la disonssion que tout >e monde est prêt .à donner ton oonoonr* pour aider le marché égyptien à sortir de la pa»se diffioile dans laquelle il se .trouve engagé. Les mesures-précocités* k oet effet ont été les soi: ventes : facilités accordées par las Banques à leurs olients pour permettre oeuk ci à même do garder leurs titres ; limitation do nombre des remisiers k la oorbeills , réglementation des reports ; les Banques se montreraient pins sévères à l'encontre des nouvelles, entreprises afin de restreindre entant que possible le nom* b e des émissions, etc. Voi’à, oerte*, nn pro gramme dont l'exécutirj) n’est pas diffioile, et s’il ne faut réellement que cela pour remoteo le marohé à llo*, il y a lieu de s’étonner yqu’on se soit alarmé, au point de oonsidérer ni e débuo’e comme une éventualité pretque 'inc vitab’e. ” '

div.head: “INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
